description: From Middle English dissipaten, from Latin dissipātus, past participle of dissipāre, also written dissupare (“to scatter, disperse, demolish, destroy, squander, dissipate”), from dis- (“apart”) + supāre (“to throw”), also in comp. insipāre (“to throw into”).

verbs.description: dissipate (third-person singular simple present dissipates, present participle dissipating, simple past and past participle dissipated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To use up or waste; squander.
examples: So much for the effort and ingenuity of Montmartre. All the catering to vice and waste was on an utterly childish scale, and he suddenly realized the meaning of the word "dissipate"—to dissipate into thin air; to make nothing out of something.

entries.meaning: (physics) To cause energy to be lost through its conversion to heat.
(intransitive, colloquial, dated) To be dissolute in conduct.
